content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between rolling green hills and a sparkling river, there lived a humble stonecutter named Taro.
Taro was a kind and hardworking man, but he often felt dissatisfied with his life.
Every day, he would wake before the sun, sharpen his tools, and climb the steep path to the quarry where he spent long hours chiseling blocks of stone from the mountainside.
The work was difficult, and his hands grew rough and calloused, but he took pride in his craft—though he often wished for something more.
One sweltering summer afternoon, as Taro wiped the sweat from his brow and rested beneath the shade of a gnarled pine tree, he heard the distant sound of laughter and music.
Curious, he followed the noise to the edge of the village, where he saw a grand procession winding through the streets.
At the center of the parade rode a wealthy merchant, dressed in fine silks and jewels, fanned by servants and followed by a line of porters carrying chests of gold.
The villagers bowed as he passed, and Taro could not help but feel a pang of envy.
"How wonderful it must be to be so rich and powerful," Taro sighed.

"If only I were a merchant, I would never want for anything again."  No sooner had he spoken these words than a strange voice whispered in his ear, "Your wish is granted." Taro spun around, but no one was there.
Confused, he returned to his work—only to find that his chisel had vanished.
In its place lay a ledger and a quill.
Before he could question what was happening, a group of travelers approached him, asking for directions to the nearest market.
Taro, now dressed in fine robes, realized with a start that he had become the very merchant he had envied!
For a time, Taro reveled in his new life.
He ate the finest foods, slept on silk cushions, and commanded servants to do his bidding.
But soon, he noticed that the sun beat down mercilessly upon his head as he traveled from town to town, and the weight of his responsibilities pressed heavily upon him.
One day, as he rode in his palanquin, he looked up and saw the Sun blazing in the sky, untouched by heat or worry.
"How mighty the Sun must be," Taro thought.

"If only I were the Sun, I would be truly powerful."  Again, the mysterious voice whispered, "Your wish is granted." In an instant, Taro found himself floating high above the earth, his body burning with golden fire.
He stretched his rays across the land, scorching crops and drying rivers.
But then, a great Cloud drifted before him, blocking his light and casting the world into shadow.
"How strong the Cloud must be," Taro muttered.
"If only I were the Cloud, I would be unstoppable."  The voice replied, "Your wish is granted." Suddenly, Taro became a vast, dark Cloud, drifting across the sky.
He poured rain upon the earth, flooding fields and swelling rivers.
But then, he struck against the side of a towering Mountain, and no matter how hard he pushed, he could not move it.
"How mighty the Mountain must be," Taro said in awe.

"If only I were the Mountain, nothing could ever defeat me."  Once more, the voice answered, "Your wish is granted." In a flash, Taro became the Mountain itself, unshaken by wind or rain, standing tall and proud.
He reveled in his strength—until he felt a sharp tap-tap-tap against his side.
Looking down, he saw a small, dusty stonecutter chipping away at his base with a chisel.
"How foolish I was," Taro thought. "The stonecutter is the one who shapes the Mountain.

He is the true master."  And so, with a sigh, he whispered, "I wish to be a stonecutter again."  The voice, now gentle, replied, "Your wish is granted." In an instant, Taro found himself back in the quarry, his hands gripping his chisel, the morning sun warm upon his back.
This time, he smiled. He no longer envied the merchant, the Sun, the Cloud, or the Mountain.
He was content to be exactly who he was—a humble stonecutter, with strong hands and a kind heart.
And so, Taro lived out his days in peace, carving beautiful stones for the village, knowing that true happiness comes not from power or wealth, but from being grateful for what you already have.
